Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Luisa Cortesi  Luisa
Instructor: Luisa Cortesi  Luisa Cortesi
Instructor: Luisa Cortesi  Luisa Cortesi
Instructor: Luisa Cortesi  Luisa Cortesi
Instructor: Luisa Cortesi  Extremely kind and very helpful! She was ready to help in every way possible!

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Luisa Cortesi  Strengths: engaged with readings, desire to help, helpful feedback on abstract - particularly with useful readings that would go well with the paper room for improvement: 1) was more focused on having each commentator say something for the sake of saying something than having an interesting discussion, 2) asked us to email you what we wanted to get out of the class and could use help with for our paper, but there was no follow up on your part to do so, 3) seemed to come across as frustrated with class when we weren't on same page as you, for example with writing sessions for the paper. That was a great idea, but we'd get what came off as passive aggressive emails when nobody would sign up. The emails did not encourage me to take part.

Instructor: Luisa Cortesi  Luisa was incredibly accessible and patient. Sometimes it was a bit hard for her to communicate concepts to us at our level, but it was helpful to hear her more experienced take on things, too.

Instructor: Luisa Cortesi  The teaching assistant was very devoted to student learning and set up special sessions to work on our paper, which I found useful. Her feedback on my papers were very helpful and she helped facilitate discussion during class well. I learned a lot from the lecture she organized about her own research. In the future, perhaps more emails explaining or reminding when assignments were due and the instructions for them would be useful. At times I was a little unsure.
Instructor: Luisa Cortesi  Regular office hours should be set up. Communications were generally unclear. Later attempts to start a writing group were appreciated.

Instructor: Luisa Cortesi  The teaching assistant was very open to individual questions and able to clearly give answers for specific questions. The area I think could be improved is leading discussions and asking students to engage more with the information.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The professor's lectures and reading selections were excellent and I appreciated how the professor always made time for office hours.
The information was very valuable and interesting, however the course is best designed for students who are able and willing to push themselves as there is not much encouragement from the professor.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The course is fantastic in terms of problem framing and learning to ask better questions. The readings, albeit somewhat outdated, were also great. And Dove's Monday morning sermons were a great way to start the week.
It was great to hear how Professor Dove and Luisa have approached their own work, as they both bring a ton of experience to bear on these issues.
The lectures which complemented to reading were very clear and informative and the discussions really highlighted unique issues because the students had such diverse experiences.
The readings
Organized and cogent lectures, great guest lecturers

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The discussion was a complete waste of time in practice. It failed due to a combination of 1) poor structure (it's awkward and pointless to have each commentator summarize a reading when Dove just spend two hours doing a great synthesis of the readings), 2) poor time management (sometimes we'd have 30 min, others an hour), and 3) lack of engagement on part of some students who hadn't read or thought about the readings. I like Karen Seto's structure of discussions - each student writes a commentary each week and commentates on one of them - that gets an engaged discussion. Within the current framework, I'd drop the ask of commentators to summarize readings, and instead just get straight to the questions. The readings were also somewhat outdated. While I appreciate reading seminal works, it seemed the bulk of the readings emerged in the 80s and 90s. Question is - if they are still relevant today, then does that mean they didn't accomplish their goals of changing the discourse? If they didn't work, then how seminal are they? If they did work, then we should be reading the current versions of those readings that are addressing current challenges of development. Frequently it seemed that I had to take face value many of the assumptions of the readings because I lacked the context in which the readings were developed. Would be helpful to have a few context articles, such as for green revolution. The paper was confusing in the end. It seemed that to apply the course material best, we'd essentially need to do an ethnography, which you can't do for the paper. Lot left to be desired on the paper, would have been helpful to have more structure.

It would be helpful to make the class a bit more discussion based. I felt like we never really had time to flesh out our understanding of the material through discussion, though I often found these discussions to be some of the more interesting parts of the course.

The reading load was a little heavy considering the work required to write the final paper. I valued all of the readings, but felt hard-pressed to read some of them so I could work on my final paper instead.
The discussions
More class interactions please!

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: The course is great, as I essentially want to do development projects in urban/suburban US, working on greening programs. Course was great to challenge my inherent assumptions around benefits of these programs, and to develop a better framework for thinking about the challenges and opportunities.
The course helped give me both an academic and practitioner perspective on international development issues, particularly related to climate, which is my academic and career focus.
Basis for environmental anthropology so for my academic background very important

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because I was bored on the first monday of the semester and listened in and it was great.
I took this course to better my understanding of international development issues, particularly in the context of anthropologic theory related to climate change and development.
Michael Dove

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
I think so. This served as a solid introduction to interdisciplinary research.
The knowledge I gained from this course far exceeded my expectations. The instructor's lectures and readings gave me a very nuanced understanding of complex development issues.
In the end yes
Yes, it provided a helpful foundation in environmental anthropology

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The work group was helpful in getting me to focus on the work. I think it would have been more helpful if more members of our class had participated, but it's hard for the instructors to get the students to act in a certain way.
I participated in Luisa's paper writing session which was helpful because it designated a time slot to get work done.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take notes and do your own commentary on the readings each week - it will be absolutely worth it later on if you want to actually utilize your time spent in the course.
If you have a clear idea of what you want to get out of the course, then this course can be extremely valuable. If not, it might be a little easy to get lost in the readings and the paper writing.

Start early on the final paper even though it is hard to find time to do so. Also, make time to work on the final paper during weeks not spent doing the weekly assignments. That will balance the workload better.
Do the readings and take notes from the beginning, this helps both in writing the final paper and tying together the readings. Also try to do as many recommended readings, they are the best.
